ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the methods of research and investigation used by historians in fields outside of the early modern period. Not all of them can be applied to my work, but I have definitely found some that will prove beneficial. I also learned about some of the major works and ideas in history that I had previously been unaware of.
Introduced to a wide variety of historians, methods, and key questions regarding the discipline of history.

A broad grounding in historiography outside my subfield. Working with a wide spectrum of secondary literature was very thought provoking and offered me critical distance to reflect on the purpose of our discipline.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I'd like to see some more works of pre-modern and early modern history on the reading list.

Strengths were getting to know others in the cohort and having space to explore methods/thinkers I wouldn't have been exposed to otherwise. Cons were not getting to know everyone, but I found the smaller class better in terms of overall conversation.

A core strength was the "introduction assignment" in which each participant chose a book of central importance to their respective subfield. I felt that this was a very effective means for each of us to get to know one another's work. In the future maybe this assignment could be expanded so participants could present on a secondary source and a primary source of central importance to their own research.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It is a good introduction to the professional study of history.
It was a unique opportunity to take risks with thinking that I imagine we won't have in other classes.
